# List of monarchs in Britain by length of reign

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg/220px-
Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg)](/wiki/File:Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg "Enlarge")

[Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II")

The following is a list, ordered by length of reign, of the monarchs of the
[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Northern_Ireland "United
Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland") (1927–present), the [United
Kingdom of Great Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland") (1801–1927), the [Kingdom of Great
Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain")
(1707–1801), the [Kingdom of England](/wiki/Kingdom_of_England "Kingdom of
England") (871–1707), the [Kingdom of Scotland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Scotland
"Kingdom of Scotland") (878–1707), the [Kingdom of
Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland") (1542–1800), and the
[Principality of Wales](/wiki/Principality_of_Wales "Principality of Wales")
(1216–1542).

Queen [Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") became the longest-
reigning British monarch on 9 September 2015 when she surpassed the reign of
her great-great-grandmother [Victoria](/wiki/Queen_Victoria "Queen
Victoria").[1][2] On 6 February 2017 she became the first British monarch to
celebrate a [Sapphire Jubilee](/wiki/Sapphire_Jubilee_of_Queen_Elizabeth_II
"Sapphire Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II"), commemorating 65 years on the
throne.

Overall[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_monarchs_in_Britain_by_length_of_reign&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Overall")]

These are the ten longest reigning monarchs in Britain for whom there is
reliable recorded evidence.

No. | Name | Reign | Duration   
---|---|---|---  
From | To | Days | Years, days   
1 | **[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II")** | **6 February 1952** | **Present** | **24,267** | **7004242670000000000♠ 66 years, 160 days**  
2 | [Victoria of the United Kingdom](/wiki/Queen_Victoria "Queen Victoria") | 20 June 1837 | 22 January 1901 | 23,226 | 63 years, 216 days   
3 | [George III of the United Kingdom](/wiki/George_III_of_the_United_Kingdom "George III of the United Kingdom") | 25 October 1760 | 29 January 1820 | 21,644 | 59 years, 96 days   
4 | [James VI of Scotland](/wiki/James_VI_of_Scotland "James VI of Scotland") | 24 July 1567 | 27 March 1625 | 21,066 | 57 years, 246 days   
5 | [Henry III of England](/wiki/Henry_III_of_England "Henry III of England") | 28 October 1216 | 16 November 1272 | 20,473 | 56 years, 19 days   
6 | [Edward III of England](/wiki/Edward_III_of_England "Edward III of England") | 25 January 1327 | 20 June 1377 | 18,410 | 50 years, 147 days   
7 | [William I of Scotland](/wiki/William_the_Lion "William the Lion") | 9 December 1165 | 4 December 1214 | 17,892 | 48 years, 360 days   
8 | [Llywelyn of Gwynedd](/wiki/Llywelyn_the_Great "Llywelyn the Great") | 1195 | 11 April 1240 | 16,173–16,902 | c. 44–45 years   
9 | [Elizabeth I of England](/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England "Elizabeth I of England") | 17 November 1558 | 24 March 1603 | 16,198 | 44 years, 127 days   
10 | [David II of Scotland](/wiki/David_II_of_Scotland "David II of Scotland") | 7 June 1329 | 22 February 1371 | 15,235 | 41 years, 260 days   
  
The longest claim by a [pretender](/wiki/Pretender "Pretender") was that of
[James Francis Edward Stuart](/wiki/James_Francis_Edward_Stuart "James Francis
Edward Stuart") (the "Old Pretender"), who was the [Jacobite
pretender](/wiki/Jacobite_succession "Jacobite succession") to the thrones of
England, Scotland and Ireland for 64 years, 3 months, and 16 days (17
September 1701 – 1 January 1766).

### Elizabeth
II[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_monarchs_in_Britain_by_length_of_reign&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Elizabeth II")]

On 9 September 2015 (at the age of 89 years, 141 days), [Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") became the longest-reigning British
monarch and the longest-reigning female monarch in world history.[3][4] On 23
May 2016 (at the age of 90 years, 32 days), her reign surpassed the claimed
reign of [James Francis Edward Stuart](/wiki/James_Francis_Edward_Stuart
"James Francis Edward Stuart") (the "Old Pretender").[5] On 13 October 2016
(at the age of 90 years, 175 days), she became the world's longest-reigning
current monarch (and the world's [longest-serving current head of
state](/wiki/List_of_current_state_leaders_by_date_of_assumption_of_office
"List of current state leaders by date of assumption of office")) after the
death of [Bhumibol Adulyadej (Rama IX)](/wiki/Bhumibol_Adulyadej "Bhumibol
Adulyadej"), [King of Thailand](/wiki/King_of_Thailand "King of
Thailand").[6][7]

Should she still be reigning on –

  * 18 July 2020 (at age 94 years, 88 days), she will have been queen for 25,000 days.[8]
  * 6 February 2022 (at age 95 years, 291 days), she will celebrate her [platinum jubilee](/wiki/Platinum_jubilee "Platinum jubilee"), marking 70 years on the throne.[9]
  * 27 May 2024 (at age 98 years, 36 days), she will surpass [Louis XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France "Louis XIV of France") of [France](/wiki/Kingdom_of_France "Kingdom of France") as the longest-reigning monarch of a major European country.[10]

### United
Kingdom[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_monarchs_in_Britain_by_length_of_reign&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: United Kingdom")]

On 1 January 1801 the [Kingdom of Great
Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain") united
with the [Kingdom of Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland")
to become the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland"), becoming the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and
Northern Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") by Act of Parliament
in 1927[11] following the creation of the [Irish Free
State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State") in 1922.

### Great

"Edit section: Great Britain")]

of Union 1707"), the [Kingdom of England](/wiki/Kingdom_of_England "Kingdom of

"Kingdom of Scotland") as the [Kingdom of Great

###
Ireland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_monarchs_in_Britain_by_length_of_reign&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Ireland")]

See also: [Monarchy of Ireland](/wiki/Monarchy_of_Ireland "Monarchy of
Ireland")

The [High King of Ireland
(846–1198)](/wiki/Monarchy_of_Ireland#Gaelic_kings_and_kingdoms "Monarchy of
Ireland") was primarily a titular title (with the exception of [Ruaidrí Ua
Conchobair](/wiki/Ruaidr%C3%AD_Ua_Conchobair "Ruaidrí Ua Conchobair") who was
regarded as the first "King of Ireland"). The later [Kingdom of
Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland") (1542–1800) came into
being under the [Crown of Ireland Act 1542](/wiki/Crown_of_Ireland_Act_1542
"Crown of Ireland Act 1542"), the [long title](/wiki/Long_title "Long title")
of which was "An Act that the King of England, his Heirs and Successors, be
Kings of Ireland". In 1801 the Irish crown became part of the [United Kingdom
of Great Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland").

###
Gwynedd[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_monarchs_in_Britain_by_length_of_reign&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Gwynedd")]

See also: [List of rulers of Gwynedd](/wiki/List_of_rulers_of_Gwynedd "List of
rulers of Gwynedd")

The [Principality (or Kingdom) of Gwynedd](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Gwynedd "Kingdom
of Gwynedd") (5th century–1216) was based in northwest [Wales](/wiki/Wales
"Wales"), its rulers were repeatedly acclaimed as "[King of the
Britons](/wiki/King_of_the_Britons "King of the Britons")" before losing their
power in civil wars or Saxon and Norman invasions. In 1216 it was superseded
by the title [Principality of Wales](/wiki/Principality_of_Wales "Principality
of Wales"), although the new title was not first used until the 1240s.

Wales[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_monarchs_in_Britain_by_length_of_reign&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Wales")]

See also: [List of Princes of Wales](/wiki/List_of_Princes_of_Wales "List of
Princes of Wales")

The [Principality of Wales](/wiki/Principality_of_Wales "Principality of
Wales") (1216–1542) was a client state of England for much of its history,
except for brief periods when it was _[de facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto")_
independent under a Welsh [Prince of Wales](/wiki/Prince_of_Wales "Prince of
Wales") (see [House of Aberffraw](/wiki/House_of_Aberffraw "House of
Aberffraw")). From 1301 it was first used as a title of the English (and later
British) heir apparent. The [Laws in Wales Acts
1535–1542](/wiki/Laws_in_Wales_Acts_1535%E2%80%931542 "Laws in Wales Acts
1535–1542") formally incorporated all of Wales within the [Kingdom of
England](/wiki/Kingdom_of_England "Kingdom of England").
